name: crossed
content:
crossed adjective
(BODY PART)
Add to word list
Add to word list
(of someone's arms, legs, or fingers) in a position where one arm, etc. is placed over the other one: He just sat at the table with crossed arms and refused to eat. The children all sit on the floor with legs crossed. Her legs were crossed at the ankles. Opposite
uncrossed keep/have your fingers crossed (also fingers are crossed, fingers crossed)
used when you hope very much that something will happen in the way that you want: We're all keeping our fingers crossed for good weather on the day. I had my fingers crossed that it would work. He's injured at the moment but fingers crossed he'll be able to play. All they could do was wait with their fingers crossed.
More examplesFewer examplesShe rested her head on her crossed arms.I smoothed down my skirt over my crossed legs.You may be able to tell a lot from the couple's body language, for example if their arms are crossed or their legs are crossed away from each other.He held up his crossed fingers and smiled.

crossed adjective
(WITH LINE/PATH ACROSS)
having a line drawn across it: The crossed lines inscribed on the object may represent the four points of the compass. She will make sure the contract has every t crossed and every i dotted (= that it is very careful and completely correct).
having a path, river, bridge, etc. going across it: The golf course is crossed in three places by streams. Opposite
uncrossedSee also
get your wires crossed
More examplesFewer examplesThe letters included a distinctive symbol: two crossed lines through a circle, resembling the crosshairs of a gun.They hiked for two hours uphill on a rough dirt track crossed by dozens of streams.The area is a desert, racked by dust storms and crossed by ancient dry riverbeds.

(MIXED)
crossed with
